articleinfo.title: Fedict eID Trust Service Developer Guide

abstract.para: This manual serves as an entry point for integrating the eID Trust Service into your web application.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document (in uppercase, as shown) are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] .

The eID Trust Service provides a web service based on the W3C XKMS v.2.0 standard for validation of a certificate chain against a certain trust domain. The web service also allows for historical validation of a certificate chain, where you can provide the necessary revocation data using or a list of OCSP response and/or CRLs or using the
XAdES revocation values element.
. Besides that the web service also allows for validation of attribute certificates and timestamp tokens.
For more technical detail on the XKMS 2 web service, please see the architecture guide provided in the SDK package.

section.title: XKMS 2 web service client
section.para: To access the Fedict eID Trust Service XKMS v2.0 web service the SDK provides an XKMS2Client component. Initializing this component takes a String location argument which expects to be the full path of the XKMS2 web service, e.g. http://www.e-contract.be/eid-trust-service-ws/xkms2 .

section.title: Debugging
section.para: During the development process, you might want some more debugging info on the sent and received SOAP messages. You can turn this feature on using the setLogging(boolean) method.

section.title: Proxy
section.para: If you are behind a proxy, you can configure this in the XKMS2Client using the setProxy(String proxyHost, int proxyPort) method.

section.title: WS-Security
section.para: The Trust Service you are connecting might be configured to use WS-Security for signing the outgoing message. The XKMS2 client will in this case automatically verify the incoming message signature using the embedded certificate in the WS-Security element. You can optionally add extra verification for this certificate by specifying manually the certificate you expect it to be using the setServerCertificate(X509Certificate) method. By default the WS-Security timestamp present will be verified to not have an offset bigger then 5 minutes. You can optionally configure this offset using the setMaxWSSecurityTimestampOffset(long) ( in seconds ).

section.title: Unilateral TLS authentication
section.para: When accessing the trust service over SSL, you can optionally specify the Public Key to be used for verification of the SSL certificate using the method setServicePublicKey(PublicKey) .

section.title: Certificate chain validation
section.para: In its most minimal configuration, a client can specify a certificate path for validation. The trust service will then perform a PKI-validation against the configured default trust domain. It is expected for the certificate path to be ordered, holding the root certificate as last in the list.

Case the validation was not successful, a ValidationFailedException will be thrown, containing the list of XKMS2 reason URIs what caused the PKI-validation to fail. These reason URIs can also be found using the method getInvalidReasons() method.

Case you want to validate against a specific trust domain off course the XKMS2 client's API lets you specify this. You can also optionally request for the trust service to return the used revocation data ( OCSP responses and/or CRL data ). This revocation data can afterwards be retrieved using getRevocationValues which returns a
XAdES revocation values element
.

section.title: Historical validation
section.para:
It is possible to perform historical validation on certificate paths. The XKMS2Client provides 3 means of providing the necessary revocation data for the trust service. Either by explictly specifying the list of OCSPResp and X509CRL , or by specifying the list of encoded OCSP responses and CRL data, or alternatively by specifying the
XAdES revocation values element
explicitly.
Historical validations are usefull in the context of verification of ETSI XAdES v.1.3.2 digital signatures, focussed on XAdES-X-L signatures.

section.title: Attribute certificate validation
section.para: It is possible to validate Attribute certificates using the XKMS2 web service. To do so you will have to provide the certificate path for PKI-validation of these attribute certificates.

You can specify the attribute certificate using the
XAdES CertifiedRolesListType element
.

section.title: TSA certificates
section.para: It is possible to validate TSA certificates using the XKMS2 web service. The encoded timestamp token will then off course need to contain the certificate path of the the TSA certificate for the trust service be able to perform PKI-validation.
You can specifiy the timestamp token using the BouncyCastle TimeStampToken class.

section.title: High Availability XKMS2 client
section.para: The HAXKMS2Client component is a high availability component providing the same features as the XKMS2Client but lets you specify a custom jTrust TrustValidator to be used in case the validation request to the XKMS2 web service failed unexpectedly due to connection issues. In that case it will fallback to your specified TrustValidator.
